dataset.title: Sycamore Creek macroinvertebrate collection in wetland reach and gravel reach in post-winter-flood succession, 2010 to 2013

abstract.para: The primary objective of this project is to understand how long-term climate variability and change influence the structure and function of desert streams via effects on hydrologic disturbance regimes. Climate and hydrology are intimately linked in arid landscapes; for this reason, desert streams are particularly well suited for both observing and understanding the consequences of climate variability and directional change. Researchers try to (1) determine how climate variability and change over multiple years influence stream biogeomorphic structure (i.e., prevalence and persistence of wetland and gravel-bed ecosystem states) via their influence on factors that control vegetation biomass, and (2) compare interannual variability in within-year successional patterns in ecosystem processes and community structure of primary producers and consumers of two contrasting reach types (wetland and gravel-bed stream reaches). This specific dataset was collected to understand two questions: (1) how does interaunnal and intra-annual variability and directional change in winter precipitation and hence streamflow extremes influence macrioinvertebrate community structure, and (2) how do these patterns differ in wetland-dominated reaches from gravel-dominated reaches?

section.title: Method Description of the Sycamore Creek macroinvertebrate collection

listitem.para: 1a. Inverebrate collection - surber sampler
The net is made from 400um nitex and a base 20cmx20cm.

Press the metal base firmly into the stream substrate. Try not to put the barrier directly onto any rocks that will prevent large parts of the barrier from contacting the substrate. The net opening should face upstream and the tail parallel to the flow of the water and partially submerged.
The substrate should be stirred vigorously so that dislodged particles drift down into the net. Larger rocks can be placed inside the net and the nitex walls used to lightly scrub the rock.

After 30 seconds of scrubbing and stirring the net should be lifted from the water with a scooping motion to swirl particles caught on net wall down into the collection jar. The net walls need to be carefully checked for clinging insects.

After straining some of the extra water out of the net and collection jar the contents of the collection jar should be poured into a whirl-pack and the jar, and lower portions of the net should be rinsed with 70% ethanol with the rinsing going into the whirl-pack. Check jar neck and lid for caught debris and insects.
Ensure that there is enough alcohol in the whirl-pack and seal.
1b. Invertebrate collection - cores

The top 2.5 cm of benthic sediment were collected by manually pushing a 5.6 cm diameter plastic core into the sediment, collecting a total of 61.58 cm3 of sample. Sediment was elutriated in a pitcher using stream water six times. Each time the suspended contents were poured into a sieve with 200um micron mesh where water was allowed to drain. The remaining contents in the sieve were poured into a whirlpack. ~50 ml of 70% ethanol was used to preserve invertebrates in each whirlpack.
Five insect cores were collected per wetted stream reach during spring sequence sampling between April-July.
2. Laboratory sorting and identification
Samples were coarsely sorted by students using dissecting microscopes. Insects were placed in scintillation vials with 70% ethanol.

A resident insect taxonomist identified all arthropod specimens using a WILD M3Z stereo microscope to the level of family and genus if possible and created reference vouches for morphological species. Counted the number of each morphotype specimen and measured their body lengths. Took a subsample of morphotype specimens when the number of individuals was large. Subsampling: Each morphotype was divided equally using a sectioning circle. Subsampled specimens were counted and measured up to 50 individuals.
Reference book: An Introduction to the Aquatic Insects of North America, 3rd Ed, Ed. R. W. Merritt and K.W. Cummins, Kendall/Hunt Publishing Co., 1978.

project.title: Long-term climate variability and ecosystem response in a desert stream, Sycamore Creek AZ.

abstract.para: The primary objective of this project is to understand how long-term climate variability influences the structure and function of desert streams. Climate and hydrology are intimately linked in arid landscapes; for this reason, desert streams, such as our study sites at Sycamore Creek, AZ, are particularly well suited for both observing and understanding the consequences of climate variability and directional change. Arid regions are characterized by high interannual variation in precipitation, and these climate patterns drive the overall disturbance regime (in terms of flooding and drying) and nutrient status of desert stream ecosystems. At long time scales, the number and size of floods in a given year or cluster of years dictate nutrient delivery to streams from the surrounding catchment, and also influence the biogeomorphic structure of the stream-riparian corridor. Embedded within this decadal-scale hydrologic regime, flash floods scour stream channels and initiate a series of rapid successional changes by benthic algae and macroinvertebrates at short time scales (i.e., within a year). An important goal of this research is to determine how recovery following discrete events is influenced by both stream nutrient status and channel structure and to thus better understand how long-term climate variability and change guide the interactions among slow (biogeomorphic change) and fast (post-flood succession) features and processes characteristic of desert stream ecosystems.
